title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Can you think of a case where a jurisdictional defect was cured non-consensually, that the court imposed a dismissal rather than the party consenting the plaintiff consenting to it? Heritage Reporting Corporation
answer_text: Subject to Final Review

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: It was deprived permanently of its opportunity, tactical opportunity, to try this in state court. Isn't that inherent prejudice?
answer_text: I don't think it is, Justice Sotomayor.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Why?
answer_text: Well, so, first of all, it has the right still to pursue its claims against Whole Foods in state court.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Otherwise, they just are out of luck?
answer_text: Well, I think, if there were -- if the dismissed non-diverse defendant were an indispensable party or somehow the absence of that defendant at the trial affected the outcome of the trial, then you might have an ability on appeal to get the judgment vacated and the whole thing sent back to state court. But, here, the absence of Whole Food had literally no effect on the Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Right. Well, I mean, this Court explained in Caterpillar that the rules -- the way the rules are structured, it puts a premium on deciding very early in a removed case whether it should be in state court or federal court. And it tolerates some sort of errors, right?
answer_text: If a case is remanded to state court, that decision is never reviewable on appeal, no matter how wrong it was.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Subject to Final Review prejudice like a necessary and indispensable party?
answer_text: Right. So I'm not it's not never reviewable, but it's not -- you wouldn't correct it if you go all the way to final judgment and there was no jurisdictional problem through that time, unless there -- the absence of that dismissed party somehow affected the outcome of the trial, yes.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: - and what do we do about Lexecon, where it was two federal district courts -- we weren't even talking about state court -- and a judgment was entered and there was no argument that the judgment in one district court's better than a judgment in another district court, and we completely sent it back to start over because the plaintiff's choice of forum was denied?
answer_text: Well, it wasn't I'll start with the second if that's all right. Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: I think I'm missing it. In one case, the court says: I'm getting rid of these federal claims because you failed to state a claim, right?
answer_text: Yeah.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Subject to Final Review there remains jurisdiction over the federal claims, but there doesn't remain jurisdiction over the remaining part suit?
answer_text: Yes.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: I mean, I get the idea that that's -- I mean, that's true. It's like, why should that difference make a difference? It's saying, in both cases, the thing that created the federal jurisdiction is gone, and the question is, does the -- the federal court still have jurisdiction over what remains?
answer_text: And -- and what Royal Canin says is, yes, because the -- the thing that created federal jurisdiction can still come back.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Subject to Final Review the idea it's a little bit of a conundrum, but -- but if -- if, in fact, you're right and that there is a fraudulent joinder, doesn't that just get read back in to the -- to the situation that existed at final judgment?
answer_text: I don't think so. I mean, the Fifth Circuit's decision, with all due respect to them, they don't have a time machine. They can't go back and change what actually happened.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: No, but that's the Caterpillar situation. You would just concede at that point. I mean, you would cure it, right?
answer_text: So, fine, fine, you know, Whole Foods was -- was fraudulently joined and we could continue to go on, but, because you win in this situation, you would cure it.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Ms. Harrington I'm sorry, were you finished?
answer_text: No, go ahead. I mean go ahead.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Subject to Final Review joinder dismissal? I mean, then your client I mean, would you want to remove if you thought you were at risk of investing all the resources in litigating the case to a final judgment and then potentially losing it on appeal? I mean, what would it do to the doctrine just from a matter of litigation incentives?
answer_text: I mean, I think it creates strange incentives, but I'm not sure you know, I think defendants who think they have a right to remove will still remove. We assume good faith by parties. They're not going to assert a fraudulent joinder argument if they don't think it's valid.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: But can we go back to Justice Sotomayor's point about prejudice? So is it your view that there would be no potentially preclusive effect of this judgment on a subsequent determination or a subsequent trial related to Whole Foods? I mean, is your client not going to argue that Hain should lose that as well?
answer_text: I mean, if they if -- that Hain should lose. I mean, if -- if the plaintiffs

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: I mean, I -- I sense a potential prejudice from having to try this twice when initially the plaintiff here wanted to bring one lawsuit against both of these defendants. And so I guess I'm asking, if we say it's okay to affirm the judgment with respect to this one defendant and it's fine because the plaintiff can go on to sue -- sue Whole Foods, is there any possibility of some kind of preclusion in the Whole Foods lawsuit?
answer_text: So that's a question for state law that would need to be decided by the state court, I think. But, even if there were, even if the state court did say, yes, this determination that was made by the district court has preclusive effect with respect to the claims against Whole Foods, that wouldn't be prejudice.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Why not?
answer_text: That's just the ordinary consequence of losing at trial, right? I mean, there's nothing about the absence of Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: -- vacatur is the appropriate remedy?
answer_text: If the absence of the dismissed defendant affected the outcome of the case or materially

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Apportioning liability, things like that?
answer_text: I mean, it could it could be with apportioning liability, but, here, there was no liability to apportion. Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: So there usually will be prejudice or often prejudice but just not here?
answer_text: There could be prejudice. I mean, that would depend on the circumstances, you know.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: But then it's not really about jurisdiction, is it?
answer_text: No. I would

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Well, again, I'd say, to be a party in a case, you have to be under the exercise -- the -- the district court has to exercise jurisdiction against you. And that never happened here. The district court made a prediction about what it thought state courts would do with the claims against Whole Foods and said I don't think there's a valid claim and dismissed, right?
answer_text: Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Subject to Final Review affirmed interlocutorily? Those kinds of judgments can be appealed in the middle of the case, correct?
answer_text: So they could, and you could -- you know, if a plaintiff were worried that the dismissed defendant was somehow indispensable, they could seek a Rule 54(b) judgment or 1292(b). But -- but, for this

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Thank you, counsel. Anything further? No?
answer_text: Thank you.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: This would be a lot cleaner case if you had appealed the dismissal. Why didn't you?
answer_text: Your Honor, because the Court held in Caterpillar that there's no obligation to seek immediate review to preserve Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: I'm sorry, Your Honor?
answer_text: District courts still retain the power to certify without the request of either party.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: -- certification?
answer_text: -- that's absolutely right, Your Honor. And, in fact, I would point out that in 1980, in the Curtiss-Wright decision, this Court held that one of the guiding principles for district courts is the consideration of judicial administrative interests. That's what should guide a court in making that determination.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: -- but it doesn't resolve the question. So my point for the purposes of this question is solely that you're -- you're saying that you were standing on a case that doesn't squarely resolve the question and that's why you didn't try to seek an interlocutory appeal?
answer_text: Not, Your Honor, with respect to the preservation holding. Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: What do you think that -- oh.
answer_text: I was just going to say, your question is why didn't you appeal.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Subject to Final Review court? Do you think you would be, you know, barred by non-mutual issue preclusion from relitigating some of these issues?
answer_text: That is a controversial question. We certainly would not concede that preclusion would lie here. I would argue that there may be exceptions under state law both because of the nature of the jurisdictional ruling in the first instance and because there could be differences in sufficiency evaluation under state law as opposed to federal law, but all of that presupposes that the jurisdictional problem could be cured and that that judgment could actually have any substance on the merits, which I think is incorrect.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: What about prejudice, though? You know, one of the reasons why I brought up preclusion was because there was an argument that given that Whole Foods was not actually part of this litigation, that you're not prejudiced by having to sue them in state court separately.
answer_text: Well, Your Honor, of course, prejudice is not a material consideration where we're dealing with the first principles of limited federal jurisdiction. And so I think, principally, the plaintiffs do not have to demonstrate prejudice to satisfy the Court that there's a lack of jurisdiction in this instance. But it certainly is the case that the plaintiff, as the Court has indicated, is the master of the complaint.

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: Well, you made a reference to the possibility that the standard for -- for judgment as a matter of law might be different in -- in Texas, in the Texas courts than in the federal courts, or did I misunderstand what you said?
answer_text: Your Honor, I think that's a possibility. I think, if it were necessary Heritage Reporting Corporation

title: 24-724_j42l
question_text: So I would ask you to reject that argument. To circle back to Justice Gorsuch Gorsuch's question about including prejudice in a jurisdictional inquiry, I just want to try to clarify it's not that you would think about prejudice in deciding whether there was or wasn't jurisdiction. It's more that you would say there was jurisdiction and then you ask, did the absence of the dismissed party affect the outcome?
answer_text: And there's where the prejudice comes in. The third point is just on whether the absence of Whole Foods affected the outcome. My friend said, well, we would have developed all this evidence about what Whole Foods said.
